Award.AwardTitle: Multi-scale analysis of field behavior inside heterogeneous media for local and nonlocal continuum theories
Award.AbstractNarration: Lipton<br/>DMS-0807265<br/><br/> The investigator develops new mathematical and computational<br/>tools for the quantitative description of multi-scale phenomena<br/>seen in composite structures. The effort focuses on properties<br/>related to failure initiation. Failure is often precipitated by<br/>extreme excursions of the local fields at the level of the<br/>microgometry. Three projects are carried out that seek to make<br/>new connections between the excursions of local deformation,<br/>strain, and stress fields as functions of applied boundary loads<br/>and initial conditions. The first project examines load transfer<br/>between length scales for hierarchical structures when the<br/>substructure is known only in a statistical sense. The goal is<br/>to provide new variational tools for teasing out relationships<br/>that connect the local field response to the applied long<br/>wavelength loads. The objective is to use these relationships to<br/>discover explicit criteria on the applied loads that are<br/>necessary for failure initiation inside composite media. The<br/>second project seeks to understand how field fluctuations inside<br/>heterogeneous media depend on the boundary data in the presence<br/>of residual stress. The goals of this project are to: i)<br/>quantify the roles of boundary data, microgeometry and residual<br/>stress on the penetration of high stress zones inside<br/>statistically defined media and ii) understand the effect of<br/>residual stress on the decay of high frequency boundary data<br/>inside the composite domain. Understanding these phenomena<br/>facilitates the design of tough composite structures for use in<br/>aviation and infrastructure. The third project investigates the<br/>dynamics of heterogeneous media using nonlocal models for elastic<br/>interactions. The goal is to develop a multi-scale peridynamic<br/>formulation for modeling deformation fields inside fiber<br/>reinforced laminates. This formulation provides the mathematical<br/>framework and associated numerical methods necessary to capture<br/>the dynamic interactions between small and large length scales. <br/>It is anticipated that the basic mathematical work and subsequent<br/>numerical investigations can resolve new dynamic phenomena that<br/>contribute to the delamination and failure of fiber reinforced<br/>laminates. <br/><br/> The investigator develops new mathematical and computational<br/>tools for the quantitative description of multi-scale phenomena<br/>seen in composite structures. Composite materials are rapidly<br/>becoming the materials of choice for structural applications. <br/>This is due to their light weight and superior stiffness<br/>properties. In order to accelerate their deployment an improved<br/>understanding of their strength properties based upon their<br/>microstructural geometry is required. This proposal focuses on<br/>properties related to failure initiation. Failure is often<br/>precipitated by extreme excursions of the local fields at the<br/>level of the microgometry. The proposal consists of three<br/>projects that make new connections between the excursions of<br/>local deformation, strain, and stress fields as functions of<br/>applied boundary loads and initial conditions. The projects are<br/>chosen to address issues of practical interest that if solved can<br/>accelerate the use of light weight composite materials for<br/>applications in aviation and infrastructure. <br/>
